    "ocr_text": "LF

Feb. 11, 1910

Mr. Pete Curran,
172 Pentonville Road, King's Cross,
London, England.

Dear Sir and Brother:

Thinking that you would be pleased to have a copy of the group picture taken of the delegates to the last annual Convention of the American Federation of Labor, held at Toronto, Canada, November 8-20, 1909, copy of this picture is being sent you under separate cover. You will please accept it with the compliments of the Executive Council of the American Federation of Labor.

With assurance of my high regards, I am,

Sincerely and fraternally yours,

(Signed)

President
American Federation of Labor.",
    "summary": "A letter dated February 11, 1910, from the President of the American Federation of Labor to Pete Curran. It states that a group picture of delegates from the last convention held in Toronto in November 1909 is being sent separately. The letter extends regards and compliments from the Executive Council.",
    "date": "1910-02-11",
    "is_printed": true,
    "is_legible": true
}
```

```json
{
    "ocr_text": "LF

Mr. E. E. Greenawalt, President,
Pennsylvania Federation of Labor,
438 Nevin Street, Lancaster, Pa.

Dear Sir and Brother:

Your favor of the fourth instant is received and contents noted. As stated in my previous letter, we will do the best we can in behalf of Pennsylvania.

In your postscript you refer to the special convention of the State Branch to be held at Harrisburg next Thursday, December 9th and request that I should be present.

In reply I beg to say that by direction of the Toronto Convention I shall, if permitted by the court, be in Cincinnati on that date to attend the Convention of the Brotherhood of Painters, Paper Hangers and Decorators. Then from there I go to Pittsburg to attend the conference of the executive officers of national and international unions as further directed by the Toronto Convention. You will thus see that it will not be within my power to attend your Convention of the 9th.

With kind regards, and hoping to hear from you whenever convenient, I am, Fraternally yours,

President
American Federation of Labor.",
    "summary": "President of the American Federation of Labor responds to Mr. Greenawalt, acknowledging receipt of his letter and explaining his inability to attend the special convention in Harrisburg due to prior commitments in Cincinnati and Pittsburgh.",
    "date": "1909-12-07",
    "is_printed": true,
    "is_legible": true
}
```

{
    "ocr_text": "M
November 24, 1909.
Mr. E. Lewis Evans, Secretary,
Tobacco Workers' International Union,
Room 56, American National Bank Bldg., Louisville, Ky
Dear Sir and Brother:
I am in receipt of a letter from the Secretary of the Central Body of Louisville, Ky., in which he advises me that the Local Union of your organization in that city is not represented in the Trades and Labor Assembly. I am sure that you can readily realize the disadvantage which results from such a course being followed by a Local Union attached to its International, and I would therefore appreciate it very much if you would kindly communicate with your Local in the city named and urge upon it the necessity and advisability of taking prompt steps to become affiliated with the Central Body, as provided by the Constitution of the American Federation of Labor, Section 2, Article XI.

Trusting that this will receive your prompt attention, and thanking you in advance, I am,
Fraternally yours,
Samuel Gompers
President
American Federation of Labor.",
    "summary": "The letter dated November 24, 1909, addresses Mr. E. Lewis Evans, Secretary of the Tobacco Workers' International Union, regarding the lack of representation of their local union in Louisville, Ky., in the Trades and Labor Assembly. The letter urges communication with the local union to affiliate with the Central Body as per the American Federation of Labor's constitution.",
    "date": "1909-11-24",
    "is_printed": true,
    "is_legible": true
}
```

    "ocr_text": "Prince George Hotel, Toronto, Ont. Canada
XXXXXXXXXXXXXX November 9, 1909
Mr. Oscar B. Hawes,
5224 Greene St.
Germantown, Pa.
Dear Sir:
Your favor of November 4th is received and contents noted. In reply I beg to say that if you can so arrange it, I will
be glad to accept your invitation to deliver an address before the
Mens Club of Germantown, but at present I cannot give you any definite promise.
I am now in this city attending the 29th Annual
Convention of the American Federation of Labor, and would suggest
that you write me again, upon this subject, to our Washington address, sometime in the month of December when I may be able to
give you a more definite reply.
Very truly yours,
President
American Federation of Labor.",

He expresses an interest in accepting an invitation to deliver an address to the Men's Club of Germantown but cannot make any definitive promises at the moment. The president is currently attending the 29th Annual Convention of the American Federation of Labor in Toronto and suggests that further communication on this matter should be directed to their Washington address in December for a more definitive reply.",

    "is_printed": true,

}

 Fraternally yours, 
 President

```json

    "ocr_text": "1027

June 5, 1909

Mr. Ed. Rosenberg, Secretary,
United Fishermen of the Pacific,
5 Astor St., Astoria, Oregon.

Dear Sir and Brother:

Your favor of May 10th has been duly received and
contents noted. In compliance with your request I have sent
to Messrs. Ralston and Siddons the letter you enclose to them
signed by you and Mr. Lorntoen, and have requested that they
give the matter their attention. You will in all probability
hear from them at an early date. I would endeavor to have an
interview with Messrs. Ralston and Siddons, as you suggest, but
as I have so little time, owing to my having arranged to start on
my trip abroad on June 19th you can very readily imagine there are
innumerable matters to which I must give my attention before leav-
ing and for which arrangements must be made incident to my long
absence from this country.

Although I will be away from headquarters for the next
three months yet you will understand that my work and correspondence
will be promptly attended to during my absence so have no hesitancy
in writing and upon any matter you may feel disposed.

With best wishes, I am
Fraternally yours,

[Signature]
President,
American Federation of Labor.",
    "summary": "The letter, dated June 5, 1909, from the President of the American Federation of Labor, acknowledges receipt of a letter from Mr. Ed. Rosenberg, Secretary of the United Fishermen of the Pacific. The writer states that he has forwarded the letter to Messrs. Ralston and Siddons as requested. He mentions his upcoming trip abroad on June 19th and assures that despite his three-month absence, his work and correspondence will be handled promptly.",
    "date": "1909-06-05",
    "is_printed": true,
    "is_legible": true
}
```

```json
{
    "ocr_text": "LF

Sept. 25, 1909.
Mr. J. H. Gorton, Secretary,
Park Employees Union, #12720
427 Spruce St., Scranton, Pa

Dear Sir and Brother:

Your favor of September 16th containing copies of the proposed constitution and by-laws of your organization came duly to hand. Let me call to your attention Section 23, of the Constitution and By-laws, which says in part: 'All dues are payable the first day of each month.' You will notice that there is no provision made in this section or in any other part of the constitution and by-laws as submitted which provides for the amount of dues to be paid by the members of your organization. Let me call to your attention Section 12 of Article XIII of the constitution of the American Federation of Labor which is as follows:

'No Local shall be entitled to any of the benefits or the defense fund unless it requires its members to pay not less than fifty (50) cents per month.'

Your organization as a local affiliated directly with the American Federation of Labor will, under the constitution, pay ten cents per month per capita tax, five cents of which must be placed in a reserve fund for the purpose of paying benefits to organizations affiliated directly with the American Federation of Labor, in the event of their becoming engaged in a strike or lockout.",
    "summary": "The letter informs Mr. J. H. Gorton that the constitution and by-laws of his organization have been received. It highlights that dues are payable on the first day of each month but notes that the specific amount is not mentioned. For eligibility for benefits from the American Federation of Labor's defense fund, members must pay at least fifty cents per month. The letter then explains the per capita tax and the reserve fund requirements.",
    "date": "1909-09-25",
    "is_printed": true,
    "is_legible": true
}
```

```json
{
    "ocr_text": "295

Mr. Frank Ryan  --

Take a comprehensive and common sense view of the situation, and
gladly engraft in their constitution and laws the payment of higher
dues, and establish a financial system that shall protect them in
all the ills that may befall them, while at the same time accumulate
funds that shall stand them in good stead in every vicissitude of
their lives as wage workers.

Not only to organize unions, but to contribute highly
high dues into the funds of the unions, is the manifestation of
the highest conception of the means by which the workers shall secure
higher wages, fewer hours, better conditions of labor and make
steadier and more rapid progress toward the establishment of ulti-
mate justice.

There are thousands and thousands who will more readily
vote to strike for better conditions or against unjust exactions
and suffer and lose in the venture yet who are not advised up to
the standard that the payment of twenty-five cents a week as dues
to the union of their trade will thus make miserable strikes and
lockouts unnecessary, while, at the same time, obtaining more ad-
vantageous conditions of labor. One is the result of inspira-
tion and resentment, an outburst of indignation, while the other
is a calm, calculating process, the strategy or battle which leads
to victory.

Asking you to convey to the assembled officers and dele-
gates my most fraternal greetings and heartfelt good wishes, with
the assurance of my personal regard, I am,

Sincerely and fraternally yours,

Samuel Gompers
President,
American Federation of Labor.",
    "summary": "The letter emphasizes the importance of unions establishing financial systems to protect workers through the payment of higher dues. It advocates for a strategic approach to labor movements that prioritize fair wages, better working conditions, and avoiding unnecessary strikes. The writer sends fraternal greetings and best wishes.",
    "date": "YYYY-MM-DD",
    "is_printed": true,
    "is_legible": true
}

Dear Sir and Brother:

I have your favor of the 15th instant in which you refer
to the several local unions of Rock Drillers and Tool Sharpeners
who are considering the subject of affiliating with the American
Federation of Labor. You then inquire in the event of these several
local unions of Peekskill, Storm King, Cornwall, High Falls, Yonkers,
Rossendale, and the Emmett Association becoming affiliated with the
A. F. of L., they could thereafter be organized into a national union
of the craft.

I beg to say in reply that it is always the policy and
practice of the American Federation of Labor to form national unions
of the local unions of any trade or calling whenever there is a
sufficient number of local unions, with a sufficiently large mem-
bership, to warrant the formation of a national organization. You
will therefore understand that the organization of a national union
of Rock Drillers and Tool Sharpeners would depend upon the number
of local unions and the membership represented.

The American Federation of Labor recognizes
the responsibility which devolves upon a national organization,",

The workers of our country have been patiently waiting for some action on the part of the Judiciary Committee to report out bills affecting the status of labor and to grant relief in so far as is concerned in the application of the Sherman Anti-Trust Law to the voluntary organizations of the workers, and also relief from the abuse of the injunctive writ.

This, you will readily observe, is a denial and invasion of the freedom of the press and of speech to discuss a question for which we all seek relief, the relief which everyone recognizes should be accorded either by judicial decision of the higher courts or at the hands of Congress.\nMy colleagues and myself had no desire to flagrantly violate",

Central Labor Union,
Box 514, Norfolk, Virginia.

Dear Sir and Brother:

I have just been advised that the evening paper, the News Leader of Richmond, Virginia, of Wednesday evening, May 26th, contains a statement that I am to be at Norfolk and deliver an address on the occasion of the Labor Day celebration, Labor Day, 1909.

I presume that this is an error and not authorized by your Central Body. I know nothing that would give me greater pleasure than if I could be with you on the occasion of Labor Day celebration. As you know, I am not averse to serve in that capacity in the past but the American Federation of Labor has directed that I undertake an European trip of investigation of industrial conditions and nothing unforeseen occurring I shall not have the pleasure of being in the United States on the forthcoming Labor Day.

The purpose of my writing is to avoid any misapprehension on the part of any one regarding this matter, and I ask you to kindly see that correction is made.

Wishing you every success, both Labor Day and at all other times, I am, with best wishes,

Fraternally yours,

Samuel Gompers,
President,
American Federation of Labor.

Kansas City, Kansas, May 14, 1909.

MR. W. L. Riley, President,
National Stogie Makers League,
Wheeling, W. Va.

Dear Sir and Brother:

Your circular without date received and carefully read.
Naturally I am with the oppressed and for the weak side, if there is any chance of upholding it.

While I am at all times in favor of strict autonomy, as by the means of this feature, the American Labor Movement grew to the grand proportion that we see it, and having a great deal of experience in the dual organization attached to this craft, which I have condemned at all times, even in the conventions of the American Federation of Labor, so you can readily understand, with these few remarks, that I believe the welfare of the Stogie Makers will be better served, and they will have better service, by affiliating with the Cigar Makers Union.
